course.name: Critical Issues in Business Operations
course.description: The course will focus on how business organizations should create and sustain value for different stakeholders in the society by designing, optimizing, and improving the operations. Successful businesses have demonstrated their sustainable competitiveness by maintaining a balanced view of economic prosperity, environmental stewardship, and social responsibility. This course will also examine how the changing perspectives of stakeholders (like government and consumers) affect the business decisions and operations.

reviews.comment_workload:
Make sure you read through (or at least glance through) the slides and textbook before lecture lest you will be like a fool sitting at the lecture theatre. Also, be on time every lecture because some important information (like tips for assignments) will be announced at the beginning of lecture. Some prs questions are also done right after the lecture begins. I remember once some students were 5-10 mins late & they already lose all the credits for that prs session.

For the case study assignments, as long as you understand the questions well and spot out the key points in the reading materials, you will be fine. Don’t be deadline fighter if you want your life easier. If you start early, you still have chance to discuss the questions with Ronald or your classmates to clarify your confusion, producing higher quality of work.

For the final exam, some of my classmates thought it should be easy (the exam is open book & all questions are MCQs), so they didn’t devote much effort studying the textbook. You will definitely run out of time (you only have 2 mins per question) if you struggle to flip over the textbook for every question. Also, in order to differentiate between A/A- & B+ students, Ronald includes plenty of tricky questions (around 6-8). You can’t even search for answers from the textbook as they are like “common sense” (although some are counter-intuitive). But as long as you understand every single word in the textbook and jot down some supplementary notes from the slides, you are guaranteed >80% of correctness. To get an A/A-, it depends on your level of understanding and some luck.

After all, this is a worth taking cc for students wanting to avoid group project and get their GPA pulled up within two-week time.

The class will take attendance, answering 5 PRS questions each sections, 2 sections every day. It accounts for 20% of the grade.
There are also 2 essays. They also contribute 20% of grade.
Final exam accounts for 60% of grade.
Many says that grading is good but I do not think so.
(Giving a D is to warn you on this fact.)
Got 77.6% overall marks but got only C+.
The stastics of this year is mostly not given. Only those of final exam is given.
With reference on last year's stastistics:
Attendance  Mean Score: 17/20 (Last year)
Essay: ~8.5/10 (Last Year)
Final Exam: 46.01/60 (Mean) 7.5/60 (SD)
My score:
Attendance: 18/20
Essay: 17.4/20
Final exam: 42/60
Some of the final exam question are quite difficult and the answers are very hard to be found in the book.
(Yet the mean is so high... Course looks attractive, but very competitive, may not be the best choice for other schools.)
reviews.comment_workload: Studying 3 month's content in 2-3 weeks, you tell me. Yes, pretty stressful indeed. You will have to read through a ~200 page book and highlight all the key words in it while understanding the key concepts and recite the knowledge (the final exam have 60 MC and have 120 mins so you may not have all the time to check the books).
